Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 12:26AM Anko66 wrote: Jennifer, my neuropathy manifested itself in a loss of dexterity in my hands and a numbness across my left foot - this was after about 14 weeks of treatment.  I did have odd days where I couldn't "place" my feet properly but it never lasted more than an hour or so at a time. And all the dexterity came back in my hands and the numbness completely went in my foot several weeks after stopping.  I am suffering from cramping in my hand this time round with the Taxol.

Posts.Title: For All Stage 4 Sisters stagefree kayrnic

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 05:28PM Anko66 wrote: Hi Julie, read your first post the other day, and can't stop thinking about you.  Sleep deprivation is one of the worst things ever, this is why it used as a form of torture.  I still really haven't found a solution to my sleep issues, but certain things help.  I suspect that one of your main issues is the steroids you're on (think you mentioned that in your previous post?), so if there's any way to reduce your dose that would help but I've no idea if that's realistic given your brain mets.  The next thing that occured to me is that your stress level about not sleeping is making things far worse.  I used to do this to myself - go for days without sleeping and get totally stressed about it.  Eventually it took some form of medication to break the cycle.  Often when I am feeling wired and I put my head down on that pillow and I know that I am not going to sleep, sometimes a Xanax is enough just to shut down my brain activity and send me to sleep. Other things to consider:  your bed - is it comfortable?  you deserve to be sleeping in the most comfortable bed ever, so I would suggest a new mattress if you can afford it, and spend as much as you can. Next:  exercise, again I don't know if I'm being unrealistic, but if there's any way you can get a little exercise this might help tire you out physically and aid sleep.  Apologies if this is just not an option but I thought it might be worth mentioning. Finally, you could try working with a hypnotherapist.  I used one for some issues I was having with food several years ago and it worked instantly.  The effects wore off after a few months but it was instant relief from an issue I thought was out of my control. However, if you're trying all these things and not getting any relief then this really is a serious issue that your palliative team should be working hard to resolve for you. Please continue posting, and don't worry about venting ever.  We are all thinking about you and hoping that you can get some relief soon.
Posts.Title: Just me again. Still sad, scared and now absolutey exhausted julie26 pallir

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2013 01:11AM Anko66 wrote: I was diagnosed stage iv from the get-go with two small liver mets.  Taxol + herceptin got me to NED, and then tamoxifen helped them grow back plus three more.  It turns out that I am now triple negative.  I am back on Taxol again and the mets are shrinking.  My oncologist has mentioned liver surgery.  I am not sure if I would go through with it.  My recent liver biopsy was one of the most painful/horrible experiences of my life.  I don't think I could stand the pain.

Posts.Content: Anko66 wrote: So it looks like my cancer has flipped and I am now triple negative.  I am currently 9 weeks into Taxol second time around, and the liver tumours seem to be shrinking.  I asked my oncologist what the next steps are he said that we will probably never stop chemo (unless it's my choice).  They will treat tumours locally (radiation, surgery) to reduce the tumour load, or if I need a chemo break but on the whole the chemo will continue indefinitely. I am struggling to get my head round the fact that I'll be on chemo forever.  Has anybody else been told this?  I suppose I had hoped that at some point I'd get to NED again and I'd have a few months (years?) or respite, but that was before we discovered that I am triple negative.    I am just overwhelmed thinking about this... will I ever have hair again?  Will my nose ever stop bleeding?   Is this as good as I will ever feel again? He was ordered there by the courts after years of getting passed from pillar to post by the police, doctors and social services. The years of alcohol abuse took their their toll on him however and he died four years ago, but at the time he was safe and cared for, and reunited with his family and old friends. I wonder if such a facility exists where you are? (I am in the UK). Your Mother's situation sounds so precarious that perhaps the courts should intervene? What is her oncologist saying? Do they understand about her alcoholism? I truly hope that you can get some support and solutions. Please keep us posted.

I remember I had to fast, and then wait for about 3-4 hours to be sure there was no bleeding. Good luck.  I remember it was more uncomfortable than painful (I wasn't sedated for the procedure).
Posts.Title: Ever had a liver biopsy? llanabeth SPAMgirl

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2014 12:39AM Anko66 wrote: Kytril really helped me.  In fact I took Emend and Kytril.  I still had breakthrough nausea though.  I basically shut myself off from the world for a few days.  All I was doing was living minute by minute, I couldn't look after my daughter, couldn't do anything.  But then after four or five days I'd start to feel better.  The good thing is that there is a lifetime limit on this drug.  Once you've completed your cycles, you'll never have to do it again. With regards being stage IV and going on such a harsh chemo, my onc tried it in an attempt to get my liver mets under control.  Prior to that I'd been on Taxol for about 18 months.  I heard that they save the "big guns" until later, ie. giving gentler treatments first for stage iv, and then blast you when things are getting a bit more serious. I really really emphasize with you.  It was the worst time in my life, and whilst I'm glad I got through it (I'm still here one year on).  I wouldn't do it (or anything similar) again.  It still makes me feel sick when I think of that red stuff.  Ugh.

Posts.Content: Sep 17, 2012 10:18AM Anko66 wrote: I think I how you feel.  My confidence was really knocked when I was first diagnosed and as my hair thinned I just felt rubbish about myself.   I was jealous of healthy people, not just girls with hair!  Everyone kept saying to me if we didn't know you you wouldn't know anything had happened to your hair.  But I knew my hair was totally different.  There was an upside for me though.  It thinned so much at the front that I shaved it all down.  I now have had a couple of months of regrowth and I absolutely love having short hair now. I hope you feel better soon. Anne

Posts.Content: Anko66 wrote: As a newbie to the club that nobody wants to join, my thoughts this morning are dominated by the fact that I had four sets of mammograms and U/sounds carried out in the last 18 months and I yet I have ended up with a Stage IV diagnosis from the get-go.  It just seems so unfair.  My last set of mammograms and ultrasounds was in August 2011 after I noticed a change to my left breast (dimpling near the nipple).  Everything came back clear so I just got on with my life and forgot about it.  I then noticed a lump in November 2011 but I didn't connect it to the dimpling.  I went for a second opinion in December and was diagnosed with cancer the following day.  I am just kicking myself for not connecting the dots in November.  Obviously there's nothing I can do now but I just need to vent! Posts.Title: Just found out lanagraves lanagraves

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2013 11:39AM Anko66 wrote: I'm on FEC and I need to have Emend plus Kytril to keep the nausea at bay. It's very debilitating for a couple of days but it does pass but for those two days I am a hiccuping and burping mess even if I don't throw up. It feels a lot like morning sickness to me where you need to eat to keep the nausea at bay. I also find it very hard to drink still water so I switched to sparkling and now I'm struggling to get that down me. The good bit: less than a week after infusion day I feel absolutely fine. I haven't suffered very much at all from low counts or mouth ulcers but then again I'm taking Protandim at a rate of six a day. I was having pain in my liver and numbness in my arms due to progression (I haven't had surgery and I have three masses in my left breast, as well as numerous liver mets). We could tell that FEC was working after 5-6 weeks. All pain and numbness was gone and tumour markers decreasing. Oncologist is so confident that we're not going to scans again until progression is suspected again. In the two days following infusion I feel like I've been hit by a truck and sometimes I am just surviving from hour to hour I feel that bloody awful, like my worst hangover ever. I've learned to manage this by clearing my schedule totally, ie. no work, no social commitments, no childcare. I just focus on myself, try to drink as many fluids as I can, eat whatever I can face, and sleep as much as possible. Sigh, treatment number four tomorrow... but I shouldn't complain....a couple of months ago I was feeling desperate because of progression....ultimately I am extremely thankful that FEC is working, but it's new kind of challenge.

Posts.Title: Day 22 on Taxol and I still have hair. Lots of it. Anko66 texasrose361

Posts.Content: Anko66 wrote: I'd been in an unhappy marriage for a few years, eventually decided to get divorced and then met a lovely guy just four months before my Stage IV diagnosis. Despite all the obstacles that have been thrown at us over the last few months (we were separate for three months whilst I was having my initital treatment), we're still together and we're planning a future together. It all sounds wonderful, doesn't it? So why do I keep having these thoughts about ending the relationship? Part of it I think is because sometimes I just want to wallow. He's such an upbeat person but i dont show that in front of him because I don't want to drag him down. Another issue is related to my looks, I just don't feel attractive given what the chemo has done to my skin and hair. He's also a lot younger than me so I feel this pressure. I just feel surely he's better off with someone younger, healthy, someone who can have his children, etc. I'm just in a really weird situation; we're in love, and yet I'm dying. I'm happy but I also feel desperately sad when I think about the reality of my situation. I also realize that I don't want him to see me get sick. Maybe that's why I think about ending the relationship but I know I would regret it. I just wish I could get rid of these thoughts. Dx 12/16/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2013 07:34AM Anko66 wrote: Sundance, I was feeling exactly like this and I basically wasn't a nice person to be around.  Some days I just seem to disappear into a black hole.  And then my doctor put me on Zoloft.  I know that anti-depressants are supposed to take at least a couple of weeks before they take effect, but I felt better from day one.  It has saved my life.  I've just been scanned and the results show progression but I'm okay, I can manage this.  I even feel happy, obviously not with the progression but overall I am much more balanced and able to cope with things.  I hope you find something that works for you xx.

In any case, we need to focus on you.  It must so much to take it right now.  What's your treatment plan?  I think what your oncologist said was irresponsible!  How can he/she say that?  There must be more treatment options for you.  I'm glad that you've posted.  You're get loads of support here.  Anne x

Posts.Title: Curing the Incurable by Dr. William Donald Kelley MusicLover exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 07:44PM Anko66 wrote: This is a very interesting if sad thread. Words fail me re. that "support" group. I was also stage IV from the start despite having had five, yes five, mamograms and ultrasounds in the 18 months leading up to diagnosis.  Perhaps if somebody had bothered to do a physical exam they would have put two and two together, but that's not the done thing in Japan.  A screening clinic is just a screening clinic, ie. they will examine your images and that's it.  Little did I know. Iwillwinthisbattle:  yes, it's bloody awful being diagnosed stage iv from the start, but it must also be awful to go through all those aggressive treatments only to have it recoccur so yes, in some way I feel grateful.  My only treatment so far is one chemo, herceptin and tamoxifen.  As a result I am still living a fairly normal life and feeling well. So far I have never met another person with stage iv cancer, and I really didn't fancy support groups, so this board is a life saver.
Posts.Title: I thought this was supposed to be rare 4myangels carpe_diem

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2013 06:05AM Anko66 wrote: I've been treated in four different hospitals so I have lots of experience.  Scotland was the best for camadarie with the nurses and patients and overall care, although this was a private facility so you would expect it to be good.  Japan was brilliant for bedside manner and overall care but they are extremely conservative and ruled out surgery for me even though I was NED (was also diagnosed stage iv from the get-go and I will never trust the Japanese system since they totally failed to diagnose me - I mean they missed three tumours in my breast despite doing an ultrasound and mammogram). I then moved to France, mainly to get the best treatment (incidence of breast cancer in Japan is still relatively low compared to Europe) and be eligible for clinical trials and the like.  To be honest it's been a bit of a disaster so far.  I have already had to change hospitals once.  I don't expect special treatment because I have cancer, but I suppose I do expect to be prioritised since I am stage iv and my time is limited.  I hate having to hang around for hours to see consultants, referral appointments not be arranged, waiting weeks for scan results (it took them three weeks to give me CT scan results despite the results showing progression), sometimes I wasn't even able to get hold of anybody on the phone.  So I changed hospital.  Things are better in the new hospital but still not perfect.  I can tell that my oncologist has too many patients.  I need to remind him who I am and where I am with treatment, scans, etc.  I know that I don't make things easy for them since I travel a lot and have the odd treatment in other countries so I just try to keep on top of things myself in making sure I have regular scans, ECGs, etc. I know that having changed oncologist four times means that I've probably missed the boat on some treatments and surgeries.  I mean, right now I'm five months into my second run of Taxol.  Biopsies confirmed that I was triple negative in February and yet my oncologist kept me on Herceptin until I changed hospitals in April.  That really had my new oncologist scratching his head.  However, it is only now (June) that I am being offered Avastin + Taxol.  I should have been on the Avastin from February.  The toxicity from the TAxol is really accumulating now, but I've got to tough it out for another three months in order to get the Avastin.  I just hope I can do this. I've been offered no support whatsover in France.  I suppose it's up to me to pick up the leaflets or the phone but being in a foreign country it's not that easy because you have no frame of reference at all.  Like you Nicky, it's not even easy to talk to other patients as we are all screened off during treatment.  And at times they way that they do things here drives me mad (nurses don't even discuss side-effects - they just refer you to your onocologist) but I'm slowly learning how things work.   Overall I still think I'm in the right place but at times I get so frustrated i just cry.

Posts.Title: SEX - Very Raw Post cancerkicker Moderators

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2012 02:31AM - edited Aug 19, 2012 02:31AM by Anko66 Thank you so much everybody for your posts.  Have been reading them with tears in my eyes.  I am so touched at how thoughtful your responses are.  After a good night's sleep things don't seem so bad after all.  And judging by my hangover, I think the waiter was right not to serve me...! Nevertheless, it was the manner in which he did it:  judgemental, direct, rude.  I left the bar in floods of tears and I'm embarassed about that too. I'm not giving up though ladies.  We did find a lovely apartment yesterday, and I am waiting to hear if the landlord will accept us as tenants or choose the two students who also want the flat. I will update more soon.
Posts.Title: So embarassed in Paris Anko66 sumi

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2012 04:23PM Anko66 wrote: Nowhere girl - thank you so much.  I will send you a PM.  I'm leaving for Tokyo tomorrow morning.  Very excited! I'm even more excited as I got the results back of all my scans.  All tumours are shrinking even after just seven weeks of treatment.  It's just as well really, as I didn't really have a Plan B if they weren't..

Posts.Content: May 9, 2013 08:56PM Anko66 wrote: Well that put a smile on my face.  Thinking of the lovely sunny Soleil on the beach :).
Posts.Title: Happy News from Soleil :) stagefree LuAnnH

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2012 05:21AM - edited Feb 20, 2012 05:43AM by Anko66 I'm with you.  I was just diagnosed in December with liver mets.  It's been truly the worst time of my life, but now six weeks into chemo I'm feeling better overall, more accepting of the situation and certainly less scared. I'm not paying any attention to the survival stats.   My oncologist wouldn't give me any indication in terms of life expectancy because it really depends on the individual.  I'm happy with that explanation. You came to the right place for support! Anne
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed pjwoodin pq2

Posts.Content: Anko66 wrote: Not your usual subject heading, but I will head back to Japan at the end of this week where I have been living for the last nine years to continue treatment.  My oncologist wants me back in the UK every eight weeks or so for scans but I am so thankful to be getting back to my own home in Tokyo, my business, my friends...my whole life really.  But I'm also a bit scared!  I'm having weekly taxol + herceptin right now....my Japanese language ability is okay but not nearly advanced enough to manage medical stuff.  I will have to rely on a few good bilingual friends. I was supposed to only be back in the UK just for Christmas (Dec 2011) but following my diagnosis I decided to stay with my parents iin the UK for treatment.   This decision was also made in light of a missed diagnosis in Japan last summer (mammogram and ultrasound came back clear) so I had somewhat developed a distrust of the medical system over there, and I'm definitely not giving up my UK oncologist!  My side effects from taxol have been minimal so I started to put the wheels in motion to transfer treatment about a month ago.   All consultants, doctors and nurses on both sides have been fantastic about making this happen for me. Wish me luck! Dx 12/16/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Transferring treatment to Japan - excited/scared! Anko66 exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2012 02:46AM Anko66 wrote: Susan - thanks for the advice about the medical translators, that's really helpful. Leah - it's great that most medical staff speak English.  The hospital I'm being treated at is an international hospital but I'm not sure if that really means that much! Sue - I'm not sure where Misawa is, but I will check it out. Thanks all!
Posts.Title: Transferring treatment to Japan - excited/scared! Anko66 exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2012 06:50AM Anko66 wrote: Well so far so good. I have two oncologists here who both speak good English and my first chemo session progressed very smoothly. As my UK oncologist warned me, the Japanese oncologists will want to do their own thing, so they've agreed to treat me on my current regime for four more weeks (taxol + herceptin) but then they want to switch to AC (the red devil one?) to follow "global standard". They also sent me for more scans yesterday which I think is a good thing in that they are taking responsibility. Not sure I want to change treatment regime so soon since the taxol and herceptin combo is working... Also no cold caps are used in the hospital so I imagine I am days away from my hair falling out, sigh. Still it's great to be back here and it's almost like I can erase the nightmare of the last three months (well almost).
Posts.Title: Transferring treatment to Japan - excited/scared! Anko66 exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2012 06:18PM Anko66 wrote: Ugh this is such shit news...I am so upset for you.
Posts.Title: PET Results CoolBreeze ruthbru

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2012 06:21PM Anko66 wrote: Hi Jibb, sorry you ended up here. Like you, i was diagnosed stage IV from the start with mets in my liver. I did 15 weeks of taxol and herceptin and got to NED in mid-may then switched to tamoxifen and herceptin. Just last week I did a self-exam and realized that one of the tumours in my breast had grown back, and a CT scan confirmed this also with progression in the liver again. Mastectomy is not an option I suppose for me right now but I had ruled it out anyway. I couldn't find any real evidence that it would extend my life span. I might still change my mind if I can get stable and it looks like I'll be around for a while though. I think there's a mental health aspect to this as well. It is horrible to feel that the cancer is growing again (but is a useful marker). Anne
Posts.Title: No surgery? jlbb_1 jlbb_1

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2013 09:11PM Anko66 wrote: I was diagnosed with two small liver mets in Dec 2011, stage IV from the start.  Did about 20 weeks of Taxol and Herceptin which got me to NED (or so we thought).  Switched to Tamox and Herceptin but by Dec 2012, scans showed 5 mets in my liver. I was re-biopsed and the cancer had flipped to triple negative. I have now been on Taxol since January this year and I am stable - liver mets down to about three although not necessarily shrinkage in some.  I also started Avastin in June so I'm hoping for good news in my next scans in September. As for liver pain, I have occasionally felt pain after chemo - again I took this as a sign it was working.  The pain was specific to the biopsy site.
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 12:14AM Anko66 wrote: Laurie I saw your post a few hours ago and I thought given time I would know what to write.  But I don't, other than it's absolutely shit.  Screw feeling better about all of this, if I were you, I'd want to just wallow for a while.    Or scream.  And then get on with the treatment asap. Thinking of you. Anne x
Posts.Title: And the crap news today is... alesta29 LauraOntario

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2012 07:19AM Anko66 wrote: I did 15 weeks of Taxol and I think it's the same family as Abraxane.  After about 12 weeks I started having hot flashes.  My periods stopped almost immediately and haven't come back and that's been 5 months now.  I'm still having hot flashes so I suppose I'm in the menopause but it could be the tamoxifen.  I'm 41 btw.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 02:42PM Anko66 wrote: Ebru, I am so sorry to hear this but I totally understand.  I got up this morning and I read about Kita and I haven't stopped thinking about her all day. I hope (selfishly) that you come back at some point. Take care, Anne x
Posts.Title: FAREWELL.. stagefree nancyh

Posts.Content: Anko66 wrote: So it looks like I'll be starting back on Taxol next week.  I did sixteen weeks of it from January last year and it was thought I had had a complete response and they switched me to Tamoxifen.  Recent scans showed five lesions on my liver, and "micronodules" on my lungs.  My oncologist is optimistic that it will work for a second time, and I've accepted that I will just have to deal with all the side-effects that come with it.  I was just wondering if anybody else has re-done a chemo in the space of a year?  Will the side-effects be the same or worse? Dx 12/16/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Back on Taxol for the New Year Anko66 Ohmydarlin

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2012 01:15AM Anko66 wrote: Laura, I cant offer any advice but your post brought tears to my eyes. Thinking of you. Anne
Posts.Title: I talked to the Dr. today... monroy01 bhd1

Posts.Content: Anko66 wrote: I have just been diagnosed with stage IV breast cancer with mets to my liver.  I first saw my consultant on 15th December 2011, and the cancer was confirmed the next day.  Since then, I've had biopsies, bone scans, MRIs, etc. but my full results have been delayed due to the holiday period.  I have finally got a date to start chemotherapy (17th January), and I am panicking because this will be almost 5 weeks after the initial diagnosis.  Since my cancer is particularly agressive I am really worried that I've lost time.  Worst of all, the tumours in my breast have started to hurt, and I'm experiencing all kinds of aches and pains (although I should point out that I had liver biopsy yesterday).  If anybody could share their stories from diagnosis to start of treatment I would be very grateful. Dx 12/16/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How long from diagnosis to start of treatment? Anko66 Kathy39

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2013 12:23PM Anko66 wrote: It's interesting that so many of us seem to have failed Tamoxifen or rather, it failed us.  I had the worst side-effects on Tamoxifen, in that I felt constantly pre-menstrual, and I had a period of heavy bleeding, and scans are also now showing a 6cm cyst on one of my ovaries.  The minute I found out about the progression, I stopped taking it . Thanks for all the replies.  I have to keep reminding myself that I still have loads of options but it's hard.  One year ago I was diagnosed with only two small mets to my liver.  Now a year after treatment I now have five on my liver and they are bigger.
Posts.Title: Back on Taxol for the New Year Anko66 Ohmydarlin

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 08:21AM Anko66 wrote: I feel for you. This is too much to deal with on top of stage IV. Perhaps lots of folks will disagree but the issue for me is that he's been hiding this from you (not the fact that it's porn and strippers but that certainly doesn't help given that most of us now feel shit about ourselves). Is it a deal breaker? Only you can decide. It's good that he wants to talk and he is saying that he wants you to be together. Honestly men though. Sometimes I wonder why we expect so much from them.
Posts.Title: Husband and strippers anniebford TKSit

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2012 10:15PM Anko66 wrote: Cool Breeze, my Dad was a chronic alcoholic who spent the last 30 years of his life in and out hospitals, prisons and secure homes.  He abused his body so much with alcohol it killed him in the end.  And yet he will still have lived a much longer life than me.
Posts.Title: Sad, Angry, and Conflicted kayrnic Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2013 02:44AM Anko66 wrote: Hello ladies, could do with some input from you all.   I was diagnosed dec 11 stage iv from the start, mets to liver, and was ER+PR+HER+.  Did chemo immediately, with no surgery, and I"m back on Taxol again after Tamox failed and new biopsies showed that I am triple neg.  I am being treated in a cancer research hospital and they tend to take an aggressive approach to treatment but I'm balking again at the thought of mastectomy.  I just don't know if it's going to worth it given that I am now triple neg and I may have less time than I originally thought.  Do I really want to spend a good portion of my remaining time having major surgery and recovering from it?  Then again, (I have heard) new reports coming out saying that mastectomy even after stage iv can prolong life span.  Any thoughts anybody?
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2013 10:06AM Anko66 wrote: Hello ladies, sorry to keep banging on about this but my nails, my nails.  What to do?  They are starting to lift and they hurt badly.  It seems daft to stop treatment when it's working over something non-life threatening like nails, but how bad do things have to get (on taxol now for 19 weeks)? Also suffered a bit over the last few days with the neupogen shots.  It really feels like the start of the slippery slope.  Sorry to be so negative :(.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Jun 7, 2013 04:32AM Anko66 wrote: Hello all, just checking in.  My symptoms keep changing by the day. I went ahead with chemo on Tuesday even though it was counter-intuitive - have been feeling really week and as I had posted a couple of days earlier I was upset about my nails and my increasing difficult with walking with the neuropathy.  Since I put the thick nail polish on I haven't felt a thing (thank you Jennifer if you're reading this).  Started to get a nasty sore throat on wed and yesterday was just floored with chills, body aching all over but amazingly no fever.  Feeling a bit better today and I have an appointment with my oncologist later.  And my new symptom - a series twinges of pain in my liver.  I'm doubtful that the taxol is working.  And my tumours markers are on the rise from 19 to 35.  Never a dull moment.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2013 07:18AM Anko66 wrote: Hello ladies, just checking in, it's been a while.  After over a year on Taxol, I had progression in my liver so onto FEC now.  This will be the third time to lose my hair but it kind of feels like the least of my problems as the side effects/medical issues are fairly mounting up now.  Having said that, I am still living a fairly normal and active life and I am so thankful for that. Wishing you all the best.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2012 02:43AM Anko66 wrote: Thanks for all the good wishes. I've just been told that I can't use the cold cap system in Tokyo (they have old machines but nobody is using them anymore).   I would say I have lost about 30-40% of my hair using the cold cap system, and my hair is very brittle and has changed colour.  So I still have hair but every day is a bad hair day...and I'm scared about losing it all... The other issue is my port.  I have a Bard Powerport, the hospital do use Bard ports but the powerport has not yet been launced in Japan.  The hospital is asking the manufacturer for the instruction manual (!) No doubt there will be other issues!
Posts.Title: Transferring treatment to Japan - excited/scared! Anko66 exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2012 07:08PM Anko66 wrote: Thanks all, and seriously if any of you (Laurie) have Japan as a destination on your bucket list, please contact me!
Posts.Title: Transferring treatment to Japan - excited/scared! Anko66 exbrnxgrl

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2013 08:59AM Anko66 wrote: I'm hoping to have this done too provided the latest round of chemo is working.  My surgeon has recommended that this is done to prevent any future "reseeding", to reduce the tumour load on my body and finally, to avoid a situation where the breast starts to ulcerate once it becomes difficult to control the tumours at a later stage. For me also I imagine there will be psychological benefits too since I can feel the two tumours in my breast.  It's not a good feeling. My surgeon recommended a unilateral mastectomy because the chances of any new incidence of cancer/or it spreading to the other breast are minimal.  Having said that, I had an ultrasound and mammogram, and was then sent for a breast MRI this week because they are suspicious of something in the other breast now. Anne

Posts.Title: Now Dental Problems Too!! readeram readeram

Posts.Content: May 23, 2012 01:31AM Anko66 wrote: Hello Angels, I remember being very concerned about the time it took to do all the initial diagnistics and staging before starting any treatment. For me this was five weeks during which time I was freaking out. However, I have since learned that this is really important as it ensures that the oncologists have got the full picture and they can make a better informed choice regarding your treatment. Like you, I have a young child and five months ago when I was diagnosed stage IV from the get-go I thought my life was over. But things will get better for you and you'll start to have "normal" days again. Keep posting and letting us know how you get on. We're all here for you. Anne
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed 4myangels RangerMom

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2013 11:18PM Anko66 wrote: MJ, as long as the liver mets are small, I don't think you'll feel any differently.  I was diagnosed with liver mets from the start in Dec 2011.  I am doing really well, even though I've now been on chemo for over a year... and I'm not planning on going anywhere soon.  I think a diagnosis of liver mets is devastating, because it is life-threatening and the liver is such a vascular organ that mets find a welcoming environment.  Let us know what your treatment plans is.

On Taxol again and praying that it's working for a second time.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2013 03:36AM Anko66 wrote: Jennifer, thanks for the post - yes, I should be putting on nail polish and until a few days ago I was and then I took it off, and then things started to go wrong. As for the neupogen it wasn't so much the pain, it just made me feel crappy all over - nauseous, weak, shaky.   Sometimes though it's difficult to distinguish what is what causing what. Going to get that nail polish on and head out for chemo today.  Going to push on for another cycle.  Scans at the end of the month which is giving me something to aim for. Mary - that sounds tough.  I hope they get something sorted out for you soon.
Posts.Title: Triple Negative Stage IV Renae64 thrivingmama

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2012 08:00PM Anko66 wrote: Hi All, I'm Anne, 40 years old from Scotland and have just started chemo (I have mets to the liver).    I was diagnosed in December 2011 after getting the all clear following a mammogram and ultrasound just four months earlier.  I was living in Japan at the time but have now returned to Scotland for treatment and my three year old daughter is with me.  In Japan I was running my own business and I'm still continuing to do this remotely but oh how I miss my old life!  I have received a huge amount of support from family and friends everywhere since diagnosis, also all the doctors and nurses who have been taking care of me have been wonderful so far. I found this board during the period I was being diagnosed and it has proved to be an enormous help.
Posts.Title: ...And you are? EnglishMajor keepingon

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2013 09:33PM Anko66 wrote: Hello Nicky :).  I thought that the only reasons to stop Herceptin would be if it's not working anymore or if it had showed any damage to your heart.  I was finally taken off Herceptin when biopsies came back triple negative.  Even then my oncologist at Curie was reluctant to take me off it as he said that it might still be working to some extent.  The fact that you're HER+++ tells me that no way it should be stopped!  It's a well known fact that Herceptin has been a game-changer for many women.  Time for a second opinion?  It annoys me though that your onc has even suggested it.  Just creating extra worry.
Posts.Title: Question about stopping Herceptin NickyJ Gloria17

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2013 01:27PM Anko66 wrote: I just moved from Tokyo to Paris, mainly for personal reasons but I also know that I will receive better treatment here (the rate of breast cancer is much higher in France than in Japan).  I struggled a bit at the beginning getting used to a new system/hospital, but there are going to treat me agressively here which is what I want.  My  hospital is a leading cancer research hospitall as well so I feel that I am in much better hands than in Japan. Aside from the medical treatment, if you feel well enough, I think you should forge ahead with your plans.  I had a lot of doubts when I was planning my move but now I'm glad I did it.  It's exciting to start a life in a new place, and it certainly takes my mind off having cancer.Good luck and keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Emigrating katie31 katie31

Taxol has been a really easy treatment for me, and I'm still living my life pretty much as well as before with only minor but somewhat annoying side-effects. Please keep us posted on your treatment plan. Good luck, Anne

Anne x

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2013 08:40AM Anko66 wrote: Hello, I've just stopped Taxol but I got over a year out of it.  I was diagnosed with liver mets from the start, and it has worked very well for me with absolutely minimal side effects.  I've had some neuropathy, hair loss (although it started to grow back after several months), occasional stomach issues, and after a year my toenails are not in such great shape, but overall I've been fine.  I think the weekly treatments are less harsh.  Good luck!

Posts.Title: Progression due to ER receptor switch? marymoir marymoir

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2013 08:50AM Anko66 wrote: Renae, I feel like you do a lot of the time.  When I first diagnosed I just wanted to put my head in my hands and scream.   I now have a good cry on an almost daily basis and I feel like I can't go on... and then I feel a bit better and just get on with things until the next time.  I think the feelings that you're having are normal (you were recently diagnosed stage iv, I understand?).  Things will get better, but sadly they are never the same.  Sending you big hugs. Anne xx
Posts.Title: Scared, sad, confused, alone? Renae64 M-Aug

Posts.Content: Anko66 wrote: So I bit the bullet and changed hospitals.  I am now a patient at the American Hospital in Paris :).  Already I can feel such a difference.   I had seven appointments scheduled yesterday for various scans and consultations and everybody was wonderful.  I even got the results of the CT scan just a couple of  hours later. Anyhow, given my new triple negative status my new super oncologist will take me off herceptin and put me on avastin.  I have searched around for info but can only find not so positive reports about it.  In fact, if I were in the UK I wouldn't get it because it's not been approved for metastatic breast cancer as other drugs can do what it can do for a lot less money. I'd be greatful to hear anybody's experience's good or bad. Thanks, Anne xx Dx 12/16/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Stage IV, single and dating? Any advice? Kaelia Kaelia

Posts.Content: May 14, 2012 08:29PM Anko66 wrote: This thread brings tears to my eyes every time I come back to it.  I'm 40 with a 4 year old daughter.  I can "cope" with my diagnosis until I think about her.
Posts.Title: No, you don't understand... Stormynyte Reneepals

Posts.Content: Anko66 wrote: I've got tears in my eyes as I write this.  I'm wondering what is the best way to deal with young children and a stage IV diagnosis.  My daughter was three when I was diagnosed, and because I was having weekly treatments, the nurses recommended that I bring her into the infusion room just for a quick visit so that she could see where I was going every week.  That worked okay.  She's now four and occasionally she says to me "mummy's sick".  Sometimes she asks me "are you gonna die?".  I don't think she has any real concept of what this means, but she must have been listening to me talking to somebody, and I realise I should be more careful. I also can't stop thinking about how much she should see when things get really bad towards the end.  At some point, I know I won't be able to look after her anymore and she'll probably have to go back to Japan to be with her Dad.  Ugh, I'm not even sure where I'm going with this post.  All I know is this:  I can cope with just about everything to do with this stage iv diagnosis but as soon as I think of my daughter I'm a complete mess. Dx 12/16/2011, IDC, 2cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, mets, PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stage IV and young children Anko66 Moderators
